entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued November 3 at 12:05PM CST until November 3 at 12:30PM CST by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
At 1204 PM CST, a severe thunderstorm was located over Garland, moving northeast at 45 mph.
HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and penny size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.
This severe storm will be near... Dallas, Garland, Richardson, Rowlett, Wylie, Sachse, and Murphy around 1210 PM CST. Lucas and Parker around 1215 PM CST. Princeton and Farmersville around 1225 PM CST. Merit around 1240 PM CST.
Other locations impacted by this severe thunderstorm include St. Paul, Lake Ray Hubbard, Altoga, Branch, White Rock Lake, Blue Ridge, Lavon Lake, New Hope, Lavon, and Buckingham.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued November 3 at 9:59AM PST until November 4 at 6:00PM PST by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT THIS EVENING THROUGH MONDAY ACROSS PORTIONS OF LOS ANGELES AND VENTURA COUNTIES DUE TO GUSTY SANTA ANA WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITIES...
.A weak cold front brought minimal rainfall yesterday for areas south of Point Conception, with rainfall accumulations mostly less than 0.10 inches. For today, gusty northerly winds will bring a drying trend, with elevated fire weather conditions across southern Santa Barbara county, the Highway 33 corridor, Santa Monica mountains, and Santa Susana mountains by afternoon and evening as humidity levels lower to between 15 and 30 percent. By tonight and Monday, a Santa Ana wind event will likely bring critical fire weather conditions to wind prone areas of Los Angeles and Ventura counties. Areas in the Red Flag Warning will be at greater risk for rapid fire spread and extreme fire behavior if ignitions were to occur. A potentially stronger, more widespread, and longer duration Santa Ana wind event could bring widespread critical fire weather conditions to wind prone areas of Los Angeles and Ventura counties Wednesday into Thursday. A Fire Weather Watch will likely be issued later today to highlight this significant fire weather risk associated with the midweek Santa Ana wind event.
* WINDS...North to northeast 15 to 30 mph with gusts 40 to 50 mph. Strongest winds near higher terrain, as well as the Highway 118 corridor in western San Fernando Valley and Simi Valley, and the Malibu coast.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...20 to 30 percent will be common this evening, falling to between 12 and 20 percent by Monday. Isolated readings around 10 percent possible in favored downslope areas on Monday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...If fire ignition occurs, conditions are favorable for rapid fire spread and extreme fire behavior which would threaten life and property.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Another potentially stronger, more widespread, and longer duration Santa Ana wind event could bring widespread critical fire weather conditions to wind prone areas of Los Angeles and Ventura counties Wednesday into Thursday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Santa Clarita Valley; Central Ventura County Valleys; Malibu Coast; Western Santa Monica Mountains Recreational Area; Eastern Santa Monica Mountains Recreational Area; Calabasas and Agoura Hills; Western San Fernando Valley; Eastern San Fernando Valley; Southeastern Ventura County Valleys; Santa Susana Mountains

.A weak cold front brought minimal rainfall yesterday for areas south of Point Conception, with rainfall accumulations mostly less than 0.10 inches. entry.title: Flood Watch issued November 3 at 11:54AM CST until November 4 at 6:00PM CST by NWS Tulsa OK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of Arkansas, including the following counties, Benton, Carroll, Crawford, Franklin, Madison, Sebastian and Washington AR and Oklahoma, including the following counties, Adair, Latimer, Le Flore and Sequoyah.
* WHEN...Through Monday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Multiple rounds of heavy rain will result in widespread accumulations of 3 to 6 inches with locally higher totals possible. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.summary:
FFWOUN
The National Weather Service in Norman has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Southeastern Pontotoc County in east central Oklahoma... Southwestern Coal County in southeastern Oklahoma... Northeastern Johnston County in southeastern Oklahoma...
* Until 100 PM CST.
* At 1033 AM CST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1 and 3 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 3 at 10:14AM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
WHAT...The combination of warm temperatures, low minimum relative humidity values between 25 and 35 percent, southeast wind gusts of 15 to 20 MPH and recent dry weather and drought conditions across much of the area will lead to elevated fire danger this afternoon.
WHERE...Much of northern Ohio and northwestern Pennsylvania.
WHEN...This afternoon through early this evening.
IMPACTS...Any fires that start may spread rapidly and become difficult to control, especially in areas of brush, dropped leaves, and unharvested fields.
PRECAUTIONARY ACTIONS...Outdoor burning is strongly discouraged today. Take extra care to prevent the start of accidental fires when smoking or operating vehicles around dropped leaves and dormant vegetation or crops. If you observe a fire in a field, grassy area, or wooded area, call 9 1 1.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lucas; Wood; Ottawa; Sandusky; Erie; Lorain; Cuyahoga; Lake; Geauga; Ashtabula Inland; Hancock; Seneca; Huron; Medina; Summit; Portage; Trumbull; Wyandot; Crawford; Richland; Ashland; Wayne; Stark; Mahoning; Marion; Holmes; Ashtabula Lakeshore; Northern Erie; Southern Erie; Crawford

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 3 at 10:05AM EST by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary: Low relative humidity values resulting from exceptionally dry weather will impose an increased risk for fire danger this afternoon. Relative humidity values are expected to drop into the upper 20 to low 30 percent range during peak heating hours across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania. In addition, easterly wind gusts to 15-20 mph at times, highest in the PA ridges, are expected this afternoon which may also help to locally drop relative humidity values further as well. Exercise enhanced caution with activities that involve open flames or sparks as fires can easily spread in these weather conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Tuscarawas; Carroll; Columbiana; Coshocton; Mercer; Venango; Forest; Lawrence; Butler; Clarion; Jefferson; Beaver; Allegheny; Armstrong; Washington; Westmoreland; Westmoreland Ridges; Fayette; Fayette Ridges; Indiana; Higher Elevations of Indiana

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 3 at 10:01AM EST by NWS Northern Indiana
entry.summary:
WHAT...The combination of ongoing severe drought, warm temperatures, low relative humidity values and southeast wind gusts near 20 mph will lead to an elevated fire danger this afternoon.
WHERE...Across far northwest Ohio.
WHEN...This afternoon and early evening.
IMPACTS...Any fires that ignite may spread rapidly and may become very difficult to control, especially in areas of grass, brush and unharvested fields.
PREPAREDNESS AND PRECAUTIONARY ACTIONS...Burning is strongly discouraged under these conditions. Take extra care to prevent the start of accidental fires when smoking or operating vehicles around dry vegetation or crops. Regularly clear crop dust and debris from combines to help prevent fires. If you observe a fire in a field or grassy area, call 9 1 1.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Williams; Fulton; Defiance; Henry; Paulding; Putnam; Van Wert; Allen

entry.title: Flood Watch issued November 3 at 3:01AM HST until November 5 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FOR MAUI AND THE BIG ISLAND FROM LATE TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY...
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...The island of Maui in Maui County and The Big Island.
* WHEN...From late tonight through Tuesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Flood prone roads and other low lying areas may be closed due to elevated runoff and overflowing streams. Urban areas may receive more significant flooding and property damage due to rapid runoff.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - A trough of low pressure sliding by to the south of the islands will send a plume of deep tropical moisture into the eastern end of the state beginning late tonight. This combined with a disturbance aloft will set the stage for heavy showers and the potential for even a few thunderstorms. The threat for heavy rain and flash flooding will be highest over windward portions of Maui and the Big Island.

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued November 3 at 3:56AM PST until November 4 at 7:00PM PST by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Long period northwest swell will result in an energetic surf zone resulting in an increasing risk of sneaker waves and increasing rip currents, then transitioning to a larger surf with strong rip currents, long beach run-up and large shore break on steeper beaches. Breaking waves of 10 to 14 feet are expected.
* WHERE...San Francisco, Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore and San Francisco Peninsula Coast Counties.
* WHEN...From Sunday afternoon through Monday evening.
* IMPACTS...Large waves can sweep across the beach without warning, pulling people into the sea from rocks, jetties, and beaches. Sudden immersion in cold water can result in cold water shock even for the most experienced swimmers. entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 3 at 7:56PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
Invest 90W is now upgraded to Tropical Depression 24W. 24W is now centered 60 miles north-northwest of Yap Proper near 10.2N 137.6E, moving northwest at 20 mph. 24W is moving quickly northwest and now looks unlikely to result in any watches or warning as it exits the area. However, the forecast position of 24W, at least through Monday, will result in strong gusty winds of 25 to 35 mph (20 to 30 knots) with gusts of 30 to 40 mph (25 to 35 knots). Along with the gusty winds, Yap can expect numerous, locally heavy, showers to develop overnight, with stronger gusts, up to 45 mph, with the heavier showers and thunderstorms. For Palau, scattered showers with locally heavy rainfall, isolated thunderstorms, and strong gusty winds near heavier showers and thunderstorms are expected through Monday as well. 24W is moving northwest and model guidance shows it moving out of the area quickly. A Small Craft Advisory remains in effect for Yap, however, no other advisories, watches, or warnings are expected.
Folks across Yap State and the Republic of Palau should continue to monitor local weather forecasts from the National Weather Service in Guam, and your local Weather Service Office and emergency management office in case conditions expected with TD 24W changes. This Special Weather Statement will only be updated if conditions warrant.
For more information on TD 24W, see bulletins issued by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) under WMO header WTPN31 PGTW and by the National Weather Service under WMO header WTPQ31 PGUM.
Visit weather.gov/gum/PublicForecasts for the latest weather information from the National Weather Service.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Yap; Kayangel; Melekeok; Airai; Koror; Peleliu; Angaur

* WHEN...Until 11 AM MST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Outdoor recreation could become dangerous to those caught unprepared for hazardous winter conditions. Hunters, hikers, and snowmobilers may become disoriented and lost due to low visibility in falling and blowing snow. Travel could be very difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The highest snowfall totals will be confined to the elevations above 9000 feet, with lower snowfall totals in the lower elevations.

entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...Portions of southeast Kansas, including the following counties, Bourbon, Cherokee and Crawford and Missouri, including the following counties, Barry, Barton, Cedar, Christian, Dade, Dent, Douglas, Greene, Howell, Jasper, Lawrence, McDonald, Newton, Oregon, Ozark, Shannon, Stone, Taney, Texas, Vernon, Webster and Wright.
* WHEN...From this evening through early Tuesday morning.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. Low-water crossings may be flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Multiple rounds of heavy rainfall will begin this afternoon, with numerous narrow bands of thunderstorms developing and training over the same corridors tonight through Tuesday morning. entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 3 at 12:29PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
Invest 90W is now centered directly south-southeast of Yap Proper near 8.6N 138.8E, and JTWC has issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert, meaning development into a significant tropical cyclone is possible within the next 12 to 24 hours. This will keep Yap and Palau in a region of locally heavy showers, thunderstorms, and strong gusty winds for the rest of Sunday through Monday. The system is moving northwest and model guidance shows 90W pushing through the area quickly. A Small Craft Advisory will be issued for Yap,and other advisories, watches, or warnings may follow. Scatterometry shows an area of winds of 25-32 knots southeast of the center, but higher winds and gusts are possible as 90W crosses the area, especially for Yap State. If 90W develops into a tropical depression within the next few hours, be alert for any watches or warnings issued.
Folks across Yap State and and the Republic of Palau should monitor local weather forecasts from the National Weather Service in Guam, and for additional information from your local Weather Service Office and emergency management. Visit weather.gov/gum/PublicForecasts for the latest weather information from the National Weather Service.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Yap; Kayangel; Melekeok; Airai; Koror; Peleliu; Angaur
